bibl.title: Ng Kew Tung vs. Henry M. White. Criminal.

org.orgName: Western District Court of the United States, Northern Division.

div1.p: IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT FOR THE WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON, NORTHERN DIVISION.
In re the Application of Ng Kew Tung, for admission to the United States. ) NO. 2897 BRIEF.

In the above case, a Chinese boy, 15 years old, was refused admission to the United States by Henry M. White, Immigration Commissioner; an appeal was taken to the Secretary of Commerce and Labor and the decision of the said Commissioner was affirmed. Get Tock, a Chinese merchant of Walla Walla, Washington and the father of the applicant then made application for a writ of habeas corpus, alleging among other irregularities that the finding was not sustrained by the evidence and that the proceeding was not fairly conducted.

Permit us to state, that at the original hearing of the application for admission by the Commissioner of Immigration, the applicant was without counsel and it was only after the application had been denied that he was represented.

In support of the petition for a writ of habeas corpus, the petitioner offered to show by the Commissioner of Immigration, that a fair and impartial hearing had not been given the applicant; that in fact, the matter had never been brought to the attention of the Commissioner; also offered to show by H. A. Monroe, Chinese Inspector, who had immediate charge of this case, that in his opinion, the applicant looked like a son of Get Tock, but that he was compelled to refuse the application on account of certain alleged statements, as shown by an interpretation many years ago; petitioner also offered to show by the record that the applicant was not given a fair
or impartial hearimg; that there was no evidence from which the Commissioner could make his finding and that any conclusion reached by him was not taken from the record, but only fro mere suspicion and speculation; that the Commissioner of Immigration in refusing to consider the record and testimony of the case in order to support an erroneous interpretation made by a Chinese Interpreter over eight years ago was guilty of an abuse of discretion.

The attorneys for the Government objected to any testimony as above suggested, holding that the Court had no power whatever to consider the same unless the offer was one which would show a fraud and conspiracy by the Government officials in denying the application for admission.

The first case cited was that of the United States vs. Ju Toy, reported in 49 Law. Ed. opinions of the Supreme Court of the United States, p. 1040, being 198 United States reports, p. 252. This is probably the leading case in support of the Government's contention, but it surely goes no further than to hold that a finding of the Commissioner of Immigration and the Secretary of Commerce and Labor can not be reviewed unless there has been some abuse of authority or that there has not been a fair and impartial proceeding.

The other case cited by the Government is in the matter of Tang Tun et ux, reported in vol. 168 of Fed. Reports, p. 488. This case only holds that a Court can not entertain habeas corpus proceedings based solely upon the merit of the applicant's case, but there must also be shown an abuse of discretion. A reading of the case, however, will show that the Court went into the record very fully, examined the evidence carefully, to ascertain whether or not there had been an abuse of discretion by the Commissioner.

And the only matter before the Court at this time is, whether or not the petitioner should have the opportunity to show that there was not a fair proceeding and hearing and
whether or not there was any abuse or discretion on the part of the Commissioner.

Again in the case of Chin Low vs. the United States, (52 Law. Ed. 369) which at first glance might support the Government's objection, a more careful examination shows that the case only decides that the Court should not go into the merits until it becomes apparent that there was not a fair and full hearing of the application.

In the later case of Tang Tun and Leung Kum Wui, petitioners, vs. Harry Edsell, Chinese Inspector, (56 Law. Ed. 672) the case was heard on the question of whether from the record, including statements, comments and references thereto, there had been a fair and impartial hearing and whether or not there had been any abuse of discretion on the part of the Commissioner.

In the case of Lewis vs. Frick, reported in 58 Law. Ed. p. 967, the finding of the Secretary of Commerce and Labor was held binding only because there had been no allegation or showing that the hearing was not fairly and impartially conducted.

Any examination of these later cases shows that there is a growing tendency on the part of the Courts to insist that applicants be given a fair and full hearing and that the Commissioner of Immigration should base his decision upon the records, and evidence rather than upon hearsay and mere suspicion. In the first case cited, the United State vs. Ju Toy, in the dissenting opinion of Justice Brewer, which was concurred in by Justices Peckham and Day, the reason for this is made obvious. The rules of the department, as explained by Justice Brewer, tend to limit the rights of the applicants for citizenship. Hence, the Courts are insisting more strictly to the proposition that an impartial hearing be had and that the record show that there is no abuse of discretion on the part of the Commissioner.

We call attention particularly to the case of ex parte Lam Pui, 217 Fed. 456, reported in the advance sheet issued Dec. 24, 1914, which we attach hereto. This case not only supports teh contention made that a finding of the Secretary of Commerce and Labor for deportation is final only when the proceeding is fairly conducted as shown by the record, and otherwise, but also sets out that the finding must be sustained by the evidence and that the Court on habeas corpus, though it may not weigh the evidence may determine whether, when tested by sound and well settled principles, there was sufficient evidence to show that the proceeding was not conducted in an arbitrary and summary manner and that the applicant, at least had a fair hearing in accordance with the elementary rules of procedure, obtaining in civilized nations.
div1.ab:
Respectfully submitted, Daniel Landon
William F Laube
div1.p: SERVICE of the witing Brief by delivery of a copy to the undersigned is hereby acknowledged this 4th day of January 1915
div1.ab:
G. P. Fishburne
Attorney for Respondent
